comment_text.mn140:1.3: The Bhaggava clan was descended from the ancient sage Bhagu (Sanskrit Bhṛgu). They received the gift of fire conveyed by Mātariśvan the wind from the god Agni (eg. Rig Veda 1.60.1). In Pali they appear as potters (MN 81:19.3, SN 1.50:11.2, SN 2.24:12.2), unless they have gone forth (DN 24:1.1.6). Archaeologists refer to the strata around the Buddha’s time as the Northern Black Polished Ware culture on account of the distinctive highly glazed polish that was achieved on the pottery of the time. This, together with the production of iron, marked a significant advance in the mastery of fire. Thus potters were no mere humble craftsmen, but leading technological innovators.
comment_text.mn140:3.1: Buddhist texts of the middle period—starting a few centuries after the Buddha—share the story that Pukkusāti had been the king of Taxila in Gandhāra, who went forth out of faith upon reading texts of the Dhamma sent by his friend and ally, Bimbisāra. This story is found in detail in the Pali commentary to this sutta, and more briefly in several canonical texts of the northern traditions (T 211 at T iv 580c19; T 511 at T xiv 779a; Mūlasarvāstivāda Vinaya 3.2.26, which spells his name puṣkarasāri, the same name as the brahmin known in Pali as Pokkharasāti). Texts of this period also know of a script called puṣkarasāri (Lalitavistara 10, Vaidya 87; Mahāvastu 14, Senart 1.135). This would presumably have been the writing system in the city of Puṣkarāvati, another city in Gandhāra, the region where the oldest surviving Buddhist manuscripts have been found. The details of the Pukkusāti legend are improbable and it is mostly likely an origin myth suggested by the similarity of his name with Puṣkarāvati, authorizing the establishment of the Dhamma in Gandhāra in the post-Ashokan period, as well as offering a precedent for the writing down of the Dhamma.
comment_text.mn140:3.4: The Buddha addresses Pukkusāti as “mendicant” (bhikkhu), implicitly recognizing him as a Buddhist monk (compare MN 26:24.5 = MN 85:48.5), while Pukkusāti uses the respectful familiar form “reverend” (āvuso).
comment_text.mn140:4.5: He had been sitting most of the night in meditation, indicating that he had already mastered immersion to a substantial degree. The commentary says that he had in fact attained the fourth absorption based on mindfulness of breathing.
comment_text.mn140:5.9: Compare AN 2.37:4.2, where Sāvatthī is said to be in the east (probably from Madhurā).
comment_text.mn140:5.14: Despite his wisdom, Pukkusāti fails to recognize the Buddha. In other cases such failure is a narrative indication of spiritual blindness (Ajātasattu at DN 2:11.2 and the park keeper at MN 31:3.4 = MN 128:0.2 = Kd 10:4.2.3).
comment_text.mn140:6.3: The Buddha leads by persuading with the Dhamma, rather than by revealing his identity.
comment_text.mn140:7.1: The six elements, six fields of contact, eighteen mental preoccupations are taught at AN 3.61:9.3ff., where they are followed by the four noble truths.
comment_text.mn140:8.4: First the Buddha establishes the fundamental scope of his teaching. The elements describe the world as it is, and on them the course of meditation is based. The extension of the four elements to six hints at the practice of formless attainments.
comment_text.mn140:10.1: The “fields of contact” are the scope within which experience occurs, in response to which one becomes “preoccupied” due to the power of feeling. See note on MN 137:8.1.
comment_text.mn140:11.1: Thus far we have dealt with what is in the world (the elements), how we experience the world (contact), and how we react to that experience (preoccupation with feeling). Now the Buddha turns to the path; instead of uncritical reaction to feeling, we develop a reflective response.
comment_text.mn140:11.3: “Foundation” is adhiṭṭhāna, one meaning of which is the “plinth” or “base” on which a building rests; the commentary glosses with patiṭṭhā. Also at DN 33:1.11.150.
comment_text.mn140:12.1: Here the Buddha echoes the pattern of his first discourse, where he first identified what the four noble truths are, then identified the duty or task to be undertaken in relation to each of them (SN 56.11; see also SN 56.12, SN 56.29).
comment_text.mn140:13.1: Thus begins the longest section of the discourse, continuing up to MN 140:25.3.
comment_text.mn140:13.2: The Buddha returns to the six elements, for which we have already been prepared in brief. The discussion of the “elements” (dhātu) now continues in similar fashion to the five elements at MN 62:8.1. MN 28:5.1 teaches the four “principal states” (mahābhūta) in even more detail.
comment_text.mn140:18.9: From here, MN 62:12.9 proceeds in a different direction, outlining a series of meditations based on the elements and other things.
comment_text.mn140:19.1: The phrase “sheer consciousness” (viññāṇaṁyeva) echoes Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 2.4.12, where the ultimate manifestation of the Self, the “principle reality”, is said to be “a sheer mass of consciousness” (vijñānaghana eva). Here it refers to the mind following absorption that develops insight into feelings.
comment_text.mn140:19.4: Such as the pleasant feelings of the first three absorptions.
comment_text.mn140:19.7: Such as the painful feelings that arise in the body after emergence from absorption.
comment_text.mn140:19.10: Such as the neutral feeling of the fourth absorption.
comment_text.mn140:19.13: Experience depends on the collision of disparate elements, whose friction or “resistance” (paṭigha, DN 15:20.4) sparks the light of consciousness. Hence consciousness, like fire, is beautiful but also burning (SN 35.28).
comment_text.mn140:20.1: This is the purified equanimity of the fourth absorption. Although the teaching is framed in terms of the development of discernment (vipassanā), nonetheless it follows the pattern of the absorptions, leading through the first four “form” absorptions to the radiant consciousness that can experience the formless.
comment_text.mn140:20.2: This simile is developed further at AN 3.102:2.1.
comment_text.mn140:21.3: The lifespans of rebirth in the first three formless realms is given in AN 3.116. For the gods of infinite space, it is twenty thousand eons.
comment_text.mn140:22.3: “Conditioned” is saṅkhata, the past participle whose active verbal form is translated below as “choice”. To be “conditioned”, is to be “created” by an act of will or “choice”.
comment_text.mn140:22.10: For the idiom “make a choice nor form an intention”, compare MN 52:4.2ff. and MN 121:11.4. | The craving for “nonexistence” (vibhava; see Snp 4.10:9.3) is the urge to annihilation, for which see MN 102:12.7.
comment_text.mn140:23.1: This describes the reflective experience of the arahant.
comment_text.mn140:24.5: To “become cool” is, as the simile makes clear, to realize extinguishment (nibbāna).
comment_text.mn140:25.3: Here ends the discussion of the first “foundation”, wisdom, which is perfected by an arahant. The remaining foundations, while each having a mundane meaning, are explained from this highest of perspectives.
comment_text.mn140:29.2: This concludes the discussion of the four foundations.
comment_text.mn140:30.1: “Streams of conceiving” (maññassavā) is a unique image, allied to the notion that defilements may “stream on to” a person (āsavā assaveyyuṁ, AN 4.195:2.2).
comment_text.mn140:32.3: The “brief analysis” here is the summary teaching around which the sutta is developed (MN 140:7.4).
comment_text.mn140:34.2: This is one of the questions asked of an ordination candidate (Kd 1:76.1.14). A mendicant is expected to have a bowl—made of metal or clay, not too big or too small—and three robes—the lower robe or sabong (antaravāsaka), the upper robe (uttarasaṅga), and the double-layered outer cloak (saṅghāṭi). In the suttas, the Buddha does not usually ask this question, so he must have observed that Pukkusāti, who had renounced of his own volition, lacked the proper requisites.
comment_text.mn140:35.2: Cows were normally regarded as gentle creatures (Snp 2.7:27.1). They sometimes become violent, however, especially when protecting young calves, resulting in the tragic fates of Bāhiya (Ud 1.10:10.2) and Suppabuddha (Ud 5.3:7.2). Attacks by cows still occur today in India and wherever cows are raised.
comment_text.mn140:36.5: Pukkusāti is one of a group of seven who attained arahantship in the Pure Abode of Aviha (SN 1.50:3.2, SN 2.24:4.2).

root_text.mn140:20.2: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhu, dakkho suvaṇṇakāro vā suvaṇṇakārantevāsī vā ukkaṁ bandheyya, ukkaṁ bandhitvā ukkāmukhaṁ ālimpeyya, ukkāmukhaṁ ālimpetvā saṇḍāsena jātarūpaṁ gahetvā ukkāmukhe pakkhipeyya, tamenaṁ kālena kālaṁ abhidhameyya, kālena kālaṁ udakena paripphoseyya, kālena kālaṁ ajjhupekkheyya, taṁ hoti jātarūpaṁ sudhantaṁ niddhantaṁ nīhaṭaṁ ninnītakasāvaṁ mudu ca kammaññañca pabhassarañca, yassā yassā ca piḷandhanavikatiyā ākaṅkhati—yadi paṭṭikāya yadi kuṇḍalāya yadi gīveyyakāya yadi suvaṇṇamālāya tañcassa atthaṁ anubhoti;
root_text.mn140:20.3: evameva kho, bhikkhu, athāparaṁ upekkhāyeva avasissati parisuddhā pariyodātā mudu ca kammaññā ca pabhassarā ca.
root_text.mn140:21.2: ‘imañce ahaṁ upekkhaṁ evaṁ parisuddhaṁ evaṁ pariyodātaṁ ākāsānañcāyatanaṁ upasaṁhareyyaṁ, tadanudhammañca cittaṁ bhāveyyaṁ.
root_text.mn140:21.3: Evaṁ me ayaṁ upekkhā tannissitā tadupādānā ciraṁ dīghamaddhānaṁ tiṭṭheyya.
root_text.mn140:21.4: Imañce ahaṁ upekkhaṁ evaṁ parisuddhaṁ evaṁ pariyodātaṁ viññāṇañcāyatanaṁ upasaṁhareyyaṁ, tadanudhammañca cittaṁ bhāveyyaṁ.
root_text.mn140:21.5: Evaṁ me ayaṁ upekkhā tannissitā tadupādānā ciraṁ dīghamaddhānaṁ tiṭṭheyya.
root_text.mn140:21.6: Imañce ahaṁ upekkhaṁ evaṁ parisuddhaṁ evaṁ pariyodātaṁ ākiñcaññāyatanaṁ upasaṁhareyyaṁ, tadanudhammañca cittaṁ bhāveyyaṁ.
root_text.mn140:21.7: Evaṁ me ayaṁ upekkhā tannissitā tadupādānā ciraṁ dīghamaddhānaṁ tiṭṭheyya.
root_text.mn140:21.8: Imañce ahaṁ upekkhaṁ evaṁ parisuddhaṁ evaṁ pariyodātaṁ nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṁ upasaṁhareyyaṁ, tadanudhammañca cittaṁ bhāveyyaṁ.

root_text.mn140:22.10: So neva taṁ abhisaṅkharoti, na abhisañcetayati bhavāya vā vibhavāya vā.
root_text.mn140:22.11: So anabhisaṅkharonto anabhisañcetayanto bhavāya vā vibhavāya vā na kiñci loke upādiyati,
root_text.mn140:22.12: anupādiyaṁ na paritassati, aparitassaṁ paccattaṁyeva parinibbāyati.
root_text.mn140:22.13: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā’ti pajānāti.
root_text.mn140:23.1: So sukhañce vedanaṁ vedeti, ‘sā aniccā’ti pajānāti, ‘anajjhositā’ti pajānāti, ‘anabhinanditā’ti pajānāti.
root_text.mn140:23.2: Dukkhañce vedanaṁ vedeti, ‘sā aniccā’ti pajānāti, ‘anajjhositā’ti pajānāti, ‘anabhinanditā’ti pajānāti.
root_text.mn140:23.3: Adukkhamasukhañce vedanaṁ vedeti, ‘sā aniccā’ti pajānāti, ‘anajjhositā’ti pajānāti, ‘anabhinanditā’ti pajānāti.
root_text.mn140:24.1: So sukhañce vedanaṁ vedeti, visaṁyutto naṁ vedeti;
root_text.mn140:24.2: dukkhañce vedanaṁ vedeti, visaṁyutto naṁ vedeti;
root_text.mn140:24.3: adukkhamasukhañce vedanaṁ vedeti, visaṁyutto naṁ vedeti.
root_text.mn140:24.4: So kāyapariyantikaṁ vedanaṁ vedayamāno ‘kāyapariyantikaṁ vedanaṁ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti, jīvitapariyantikaṁ vedanaṁ vedayamāno ‘jīvitapariyantikaṁ vedanaṁ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti,
root_text.mn140:24.5: ‘kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā uddhaṁ jīvitapariyādānā idheva sabbavedayitāni anabhinanditāni sītībhavissantī’ti pajānāti.
root_text.mn140:24.6: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhu, telañca paṭicca vaṭṭiñca paṭicca telappadīpo jhāyati;
root_text.mn140:24.7: tasseva telassa ca vaṭṭiyā ca pariyādānā aññassa ca anupahārā anāhāro nibbāyati;
root_text.mn140:24.8: evameva kho, bhikkhu, kāyapariyantikaṁ vedanaṁ vedayamāno ‘kāyapariyantikaṁ vedanaṁ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti, jīvitapariyantikaṁ vedanaṁ vedayamāno ‘jīvitapariyantikaṁ vedanaṁ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti,
root_text.mn140:24.9: ‘kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā uddhaṁ jīvitapariyādānā idheva sabbavedayitāni anabhinanditāni sītībhavissantī’ti pajānāti.
root_text.mn140:25.1: Tasmā evaṁ samannāgato bhikkhu iminā paramena paññādhiṭṭhānena samannāgato hoti.
root_text.mn140:25.2: Esā hi, bhikkhu, paramā ariyā paññā yadidaṁ—
root_text.mn140:26.1: Tassa sā vimutti sacce ṭhitā akuppā hoti.
root_text.mn140:26.2: Tañhi, bhikkhu, musā yaṁ mosadhammaṁ, taṁ saccaṁ yaṁ amosadhammaṁ nibbānaṁ.
root_text.mn140:26.3: Tasmā evaṁ samannāgato bhikkhu iminā paramena saccādhiṭṭhānena samannāgato hoti.
root_text.mn140:27.1: Tasseva kho pana pubbe aviddasuno upadhī honti samattā samādinnā.
root_text.mn140:27.2: Tyāssa pahīnā honti ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṁ anuppādadhammā.
root_text.mn140:27.3: Tasmā evaṁ samannāgato bhikkhu iminā paramena cāgādhiṭṭhānena samannāgato hoti.
root_text.mn140:27.4: Eso hi, bhikkhu, paramo ariyo cāgo yadidaṁ—
root_text.mn140:28.1: Tasseva kho pana pubbe aviddasuno abhijjhā hoti chando sārāgo.
root_text.mn140:28.2: Svāssa pahīno hoti ucchinnamūlo tālāvatthukato anabhāvaṅkato āyatiṁ anuppādadhammo.
root_text.mn140:28.3: Tasseva kho pana pubbe aviddasuno āghāto hoti byāpādo sampadoso.
root_text.mn140:28.4: Svāssa pahīno hoti ucchinnamūlo tālāvatthukato anabhāvaṅkato āyatiṁ anuppādadhammo.
root_text.mn140:28.5: Tasseva kho pana pubbe aviddasuno avijjā hoti sammoho.
root_text.mn140:28.6: Svāssa pahīno hoti ucchinnamūlo tālāvatthukato anabhāvaṅkato āyatiṁ anuppādadhammo.
root_text.mn140:28.7: Tasmā evaṁ samannāgato bhikkhu iminā paramena upasamādhiṭṭhānena samannāgato hoti.
root_text.mn140:28.8: Eso hi, bhikkhu, paramo ariyo upasamo yadidaṁ—
root_text.mn140:29.1: ‘Paññaṁ nappamajjeyya, saccamanurakkheyya, cāgamanubrūheyya, santimeva so sikkheyyā’ti—
root_text.mn140:29.2: iti yaṁ taṁ vuttaṁ, idametaṁ paṭicca vuttaṁ.
root_text.mn140:30.1: ‘Yattha ṭhitaṁ maññassavā nappavattanti, maññassave kho pana nappavattamāne muni santoti vuccatī’ti—
root_text.mn140:30.2: iti kho panetaṁ vuttaṁ. Kiñcetaṁ paṭicca vuttaṁ?
root_text.mn140:31.1: ‘Asmī’ti, bhikkhu, maññitametaṁ, ‘ayamahamasmī’ti maññitametaṁ, ‘bhavissan’ti maññitametaṁ, ‘na bhavissan’ti maññitametaṁ, ‘rūpī bhavissan’ti maññitametaṁ, ‘arūpī bhavissan’ti maññitametaṁ, ‘saññī bhavissan’ti maññitametaṁ, ‘asaññī bhavissan’ti maññitametaṁ, ‘nevasaññīnāsaññī bhavissan’ti maññitametaṁ.
root_text.mn140:31.2: Maññitaṁ, bhikkhu, rogo maññitaṁ gaṇḍo maññitaṁ sallaṁ.
root_text.mn140:31.3: Sabbamaññitānaṁ tveva, bhikkhu, samatikkamā muni santoti vuccati.
root_text.mn140:31.4: Muni kho pana, bhikkhu, santo na jāyati, na jīyati, na mīyati, na kuppati, na piheti.
root_text.mn140:31.5: Tañhissa, bhikkhu, natthi yena jāyetha, ajāyamāno kiṁ jīyissati, ajīyamāno kiṁ mīyissati, amīyamāno kiṁ kuppissati, akuppamāno kissa pihessati?
root_text.mn140:32.1: ‘Yattha ṭhitaṁ maññassavā nappavattanti, maññassave kho pana nappavattamāne muni santoti vuccatī’ti—
root_text.mn140:32.2: iti yaṁ taṁ vuttaṁ, idametaṁ paṭicca vuttaṁ.
root_text.mn140:32.3: Imaṁ kho me tvaṁ, bhikkhu, saṅkhittena chadhātuvibhaṅgaṁ dhārehī”ti.
root_text.mn140:33.2: “satthā kira me anuppatto, sugato kira me anuppatto, sammāsambuddho kira me anuppatto”ti uṭṭhāyāsanā ekaṁsaṁ cīvaraṁ katvā bhagavato pādesu sirasā nipatitvā bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn140:33.3: “accayo maṁ, bhante, accagamā yathābālaṁ yathāmūḷhaṁ yathāakusalaṁ, yohaṁ bhagavantaṁ āvusovādena samudācaritabbaṁ amaññissaṁ.
root_text.mn140:33.4: Tassa me, bhante, bhagavā accayaṁ accayato paṭiggaṇhātu āyatiṁ saṁvarāyā”ti.
root_text.mn140:33.5: “Taggha tvaṁ, bhikkhu, accayo accagamā yathābālaṁ yathāmūḷhaṁ yathāakusalaṁ, yaṁ maṁ tvaṁ āvusovādena samudācaritabbaṁ amaññittha.
root_text.mn140:33.6: Yato ca kho tvaṁ, bhikkhu, accayaṁ accayato disvā yathādhammaṁ paṭikarosi, taṁ te mayaṁ paṭiggaṇhāma.
root_text.mn140:33.7: Vuddhihesā, bhikkhu, ariyassa vinaye yo accayaṁ accayato disvā yathādhammaṁ paṭikaroti, āyatiṁ saṁvaraṁ āpajjatī”ti.
root_text.mn140:35.1: Atha kho āyasmā pukkusāti bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṁ katvā pattacīvarapariyesanaṁ pakkāmi.
root_text.mn140:35.2: Atha kho āyasmantaṁ pukkusātiṁ pattacīvarapariyesanaṁ carantaṁ vibbhantā gāvī jīvitā voropesi.
root_text.mn140:36.1: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṁsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu. Ekamantaṁ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṁ etadavocuṁ:
root_text.mn140:36.2: “yo so, bhante, pukkusāti nāma kulaputto bhagavatā saṅkhittena ovādena ovadito so kālaṅkato.
root_text.mn140:36.4: “Paṇḍito, bhikkhave, pukkusāti kulaputto paccapādi dhammassānudhammaṁ, na ca maṁ dhammādhikaraṇaṁ vihesesi.
root_text.mn140:36.5: Pukkusāti, bhikkhave, kulaputto pañcannaṁ orambhāgiyānaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā opapātiko tattha parinibbāyī anāvattidhammo tasmā lokā”ti.
root_text.mn140:36.7: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandunti.

translation_text.mn140:1.2: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the Magadhan lands when he arrived at Rājagaha.
translation_text.mn140:1.3: He went to see Bhaggava the potter, and said,
translation_text.mn140:2.1: “Bhaggava, if it is no trouble, I’d like to spend a single night in your workshop.”
translation_text.mn140:2.3: But there’s a renunciate already staying there.
translation_text.mn140:2.4: If he allows it, sir, you may stay as long as you please.”
translation_text.mn140:3.1: Now at that time a gentleman named Pukkusāti had gone forth out of faith from the lay life to homelessness in the Buddha’s name.
translation_text.mn140:3.2: And it was he who had first taken up residence in the workshop.
translation_text.mn140:3.3: Then the Buddha approached Venerable Pukkusāti and said,
translation_text.mn140:3.4: “Mendicant, if it is no trouble, I’d like to spend a single night in the workshop.”
translation_text.mn140:3.6: Stay as long as you please.”
translation_text.mn140:4.1: Then the Buddha entered the workshop and spread out a grass mat to one side. He sat down cross-legged, set his body straight, and established mindfulness in his presence.
translation_text.mn140:4.2: He spent much of the night sitting in meditation,
translation_text.mn140:4.4: Then it occurred to the Buddha,
translation_text.mn140:4.7: So the Buddha said to Pukkusāti,
translation_text.mn140:5.1: “In whose name have you gone forth, mendicant? Who is your Teacher? Whose teaching do you believe in?”
translation_text.mn140:5.2: “Reverend, there is the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family.
translation_text.mn140:5.4: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
translation_text.mn140:5.5: I’ve gone forth in his name.
translation_text.mn140:5.6: That Blessed One is my Teacher,
translation_text.mn140:5.7: and I believe in his teaching.”
translation_text.mn140:5.8: “But mendicant, where is the Blessed One at present, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha?”
translation_text.mn140:5.9: “In the northern lands there is a city named Sāvatthī.
translation_text.mn140:5.10: There the Blessed One is now staying, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.”
translation_text.mn140:5.11: “But have you ever seen that Buddha?
translation_text.mn140:5.12: Would you recognize him if you saw him?”
translation_text.mn140:5.14: and I wouldn’t recognize him if I did.”
translation_text.mn140:6.1: Then it occurred to the Buddha,
translation_text.mn140:6.2: “This gentleman has gone forth in my name.
translation_text.mn140:6.3: Why don’t I teach him the Dhamma?”
translation_text.mn140:6.4: So the Buddha said to Pukkusāti,
translation_text.mn140:6.5: “Mendicant, I shall teach you the Dhamma.
translation_text.mn140:6.6: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
translation_text.mn140:7.1: “‘This person has six elements, six fields of contact, eighteen mental preoccupations, and four foundations.
translation_text.mn140:7.2: Where they stand, the streams of conceiving do not flow. And where the streams of conceiving do not flow, they are called a sage at peace.
translation_text.mn140:7.3: Do not neglect wisdom; preserve truth; foster generosity; and train only for peace.’
translation_text.mn140:7.4: This is the summary recital for the analysis of the elements.
translation_text.mn140:8.2: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?
translation_text.mn140:8.4: the elements of earth, water, fire, air, space, and consciousness.
translation_text.mn140:8.6: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.
translation_text.mn140:9.1: ‘This person has six fields of contact.’
translation_text.mn140:9.2: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?
translation_text.mn140:9.3: The fields of contact of the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.
translation_text.mn140:9.4: ‘This person has six fields of contact.’
translation_text.mn140:9.5: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.
translation_text.mn140:10.2: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?
translation_text.mn140:10.3: Seeing a sight with the eye, one is preoccupied with a sight that’s a basis for happiness or sadness or equanimity.
translation_text.mn140:10.4: Hearing a sound with the ear …
translation_text.mn140:10.5: Smelling an odor with the nose …
translation_text.mn140:10.6: Tasting a flavor with the tongue …
translation_text.mn140:10.7: Feeling a touch with the body …
translation_text.mn140:10.8: Becoming conscious of an idea with the mind, one is preoccupied with an idea that’s a basis for happiness or sadness or equanimity.
translation_text.mn140:10.9: So there are six preoccupations with happiness, six preoccupations with sadness, and six preoccupations with equanimity.
translation_text.mn140:10.11: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.
translation_text.mn140:11.2: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?
translation_text.mn140:11.3: The foundations of wisdom, truth, generosity, and peace.
translation_text.mn140:11.5: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.
translation_text.mn140:12.1: ‘Do not neglect wisdom; preserve truth; foster generosity; and train only for peace.’
translation_text.mn140:12.2: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?
translation_text.mn140:13.1: And how does one not neglect wisdom?
translation_text.mn140:13.3: the elements of earth, water, fire, air, space, and consciousness.
translation_text.mn140:14.1: And what is the earth element?
translation_text.mn140:14.2: The earth element may be interior or exterior.
translation_text.mn140:14.3: And what is the interior earth element?
translation_text.mn140:14.4: Anything internal, personal, that’s hard, solid, and appropriated. This includes:
translation_text.mn140:14.5: head hair, body hair, nails, teeth, skin, flesh, sinews, bones, bone marrow, kidneys, heart, liver, diaphragm, spleen, lungs, intestines, mesentery, undigested food, feces, or anything else internal, personal, that’s hard, solid, and appropriated.
translation_text.mn140:14.6: This is called the interior earth element.
translation_text.mn140:14.7: The interior earth element and the exterior earth element are just the earth element.
translation_text.mn140:14.8: This should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
translation_text.mn140:14.9: When you truly see with right understanding, you grow disillusioned with the earth element, detaching the mind from the earth element.
translation_text.mn140:15.1: And what is the water element?
translation_text.mn140:15.2: The water element may be interior or exterior.
translation_text.mn140:15.3: And what is the interior water element?
translation_text.mn140:15.4: Anything internal, personal, that’s water, watery, and appropriated. This includes:
translation_text.mn140:15.5: bile, phlegm, pus, blood, sweat, fat, tears, grease, saliva, snot, synovial fluid, urine, or anything else internal, personal, that’s water, watery, and appropriated.
translation_text.mn140:15.6: This is called the interior water element.
translation_text.mn140:15.7: The interior water element and the exterior water element are just the water element.
translation_text.mn140:15.8: This should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
translation_text.mn140:15.9: When you truly see with right understanding, you grow disillusioned with the water element, detaching the mind from the water element.
translation_text.mn140:16.1: And what is the fire element?
translation_text.mn140:16.2: The fire element may be interior or exterior.
translation_text.mn140:16.3: And what is the interior fire element?
translation_text.mn140:16.4: Anything internal, personal, that’s fire, fiery, and appropriated. This includes:
translation_text.mn140:16.5: that which warms, that which ages, that which heats you up when feverish, that which properly digests food and drink; or anything else internal, personal, that’s fire, fiery, and appropriated.
translation_text.mn140:16.6: This is called the interior fire element.
translation_text.mn140:16.7: The interior fire element and the exterior fire element are just the fire element.
translation_text.mn140:16.8: This should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
translation_text.mn140:16.9: When you truly see with right understanding, you grow disillusioned with the fire element, detaching the mind from the fire element.
translation_text.mn140:17.1: And what is the air element?
translation_text.mn140:17.2: The air element may be interior or exterior.
translation_text.mn140:17.3: And what is the interior air element?
translation_text.mn140:17.4: Anything internal, personal, that’s air, airy, and appropriated. This includes:
translation_text.mn140:17.5: winds that go up or down, winds in the belly or the bowels, winds that flow through the limbs, in-breaths and out-breaths; or anything else internal, personal, that’s air, airy, and appropriated.
translation_text.mn140:17.6: This is called the interior air element.
translation_text.mn140:17.7: The interior air element and the exterior air element are just the air element.
translation_text.mn140:17.8: This should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
translation_text.mn140:17.9: When you truly see with right understanding, you grow disillusioned with the air element, detaching the mind from the air element.
translation_text.mn140:18.1: And what is the space element?
translation_text.mn140:18.2: The space element may be interior or exterior.
translation_text.mn140:18.3: And what is the interior space element?
translation_text.mn140:18.4: Anything internal, personal, that’s space, spacious, and appropriated. This includes:
translation_text.mn140:18.5: the ear canals, nostrils, and mouth; and the space for swallowing what is eaten and drunk, the space where it stays, and the space for excreting it from the nether regions; or anything else internal, personal, that’s space, spacious, and appropriated.
translation_text.mn140:18.6: This is called the interior space element.
translation_text.mn140:18.7: The interior space element and the exterior space element are just the space element.
translation_text.mn140:18.8: This should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
translation_text.mn140:18.9: When you truly see with right understanding, you grow disillusioned with the space element, detaching the mind from the space element.
translation_text.mn140:19.1: What remains is sheer consciousness, pure and bright.
translation_text.mn140:19.2: And what does that consciousness know?
translation_text.mn140:19.4: Pleasant feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as pleasant.
translation_text.mn140:19.5: When they feel a pleasant feeling, they know: ‘I feel a pleasant feeling.’
translation_text.mn140:19.6: They know: ‘With the cessation of that contact to be experienced as pleasant, the corresponding pleasant feeling ceases and stops.’
translation_text.mn140:19.7: Painful feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as painful.
translation_text.mn140:19.8: When they feel a painful feeling, they know: ‘I feel a painful feeling.’
translation_text.mn140:19.9: They know: ‘With the cessation of that contact to be experienced as painful, the corresponding painful feeling ceases and stops.’
translation_text.mn140:19.10: Neutral feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as neutral.
translation_text.mn140:19.11: When they feel a neutral feeling, they know: ‘I feel a neutral feeling.’
translation_text.mn140:19.12: They know: ‘With the cessation of that contact to be experienced as neutral, the corresponding neutral feeling ceases and stops.’
translation_text.mn140:19.13: When you rub two sticks together, heat is generated and fire is produced. But when you part the sticks and lay them aside, any corresponding heat ceases and stops.
translation_text.mn140:19.14: In the same way, pleasant feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as pleasant. …
translation_text.mn140:19.22: They know: ‘With the cessation of that contact to be experienced as neutral, the corresponding neutral feeling ceases and stops.’
translation_text.mn140:20.1: There remains only equanimity, pure, bright, pliable, workable, and radiant.
translation_text.mn140:20.2: It’s like when a deft goldsmith or a goldsmith’s apprentice prepares a forge, fires the crucible, picks up some native gold with tongs and puts it in the crucible. From time to time they fan it, from time to time they sprinkle water on it, and from time to time they just watch over it. That native gold becomes pliable, workable, and radiant, not brittle, and is ready to be worked. Then the goldsmith can successfully create any kind of ornament they want, whether a bracelet, earrings, a necklace, or a golden garland.
translation_text.mn140:20.3: In the same way, there remains only equanimity, pure, bright, pliable, workable, and radiant.
translation_text.mn140:21.2: ‘If I were to apply this equanimity, so pure and bright, to the dimension of infinite space, and develop my mind accordingly,
translation_text.mn140:21.3: this equanimity of mine, relying on that and grasping it, would remain for a very long time.
translation_text.mn140:21.4: If I were to apply this equanimity, so pure and bright, to the dimension of infinite consciousness, and develop my mind accordingly,
translation_text.mn140:21.5: this equanimity of mine, relying on that and grasping it, would remain for a very long time.
translation_text.mn140:21.6: If I were to apply this equanimity, so pure and bright, to the dimension of nothingness, and develop my mind accordingly,
translation_text.mn140:21.7: this equanimity of mine, relying on that and grasping it, would remain for a very long time.
translation_text.mn140:21.8: If I were to apply this equanimity, so pure and bright, to the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, and develop my mind accordingly,
translation_text.mn140:21.9: this equanimity of mine, relying on that and grasping it, would remain for a very long time.’
translation_text.mn140:22.2: ‘If I were to apply this equanimity, so pure and bright, to the dimension of infinite space, my mind would develop accordingly.
translation_text.mn140:22.4: If I were to apply this equanimity, so pure and bright, to the dimension of infinite consciousness …
translation_text.mn140:22.8: neither perception nor non-perception, my mind would develop accordingly.
translation_text.mn140:22.10: They neither make a choice nor form an intention for existence or nonexistence.
translation_text.mn140:22.11: Because of this, they don’t grasp at anything in the world.
translation_text.mn140:22.12: Not grasping, they’re not anxious. Not being anxious, they personally become extinguished.
translation_text.mn140:22.13: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’
translation_text.mn140:23.1: If they feel a pleasant feeling, they understand that it’s impermanent, that they’re not attached to it, and that they don’t take pleasure in it.
translation_text.mn140:23.2: If they feel a painful feeling, they understand that it’s impermanent, that they’re not attached to it, and that they don’t take pleasure in it.
translation_text.mn140:23.3: If they feel a neutral feeling, they understand that it’s impermanent, that they’re not attached to it, and that they don’t take pleasure in it.
translation_text.mn140:24.1: If they feel a pleasant feeling, they feel it detached.
translation_text.mn140:24.2: If they feel a painful feeling, they feel it detached.
translation_text.mn140:24.3: If they feel a neutral feeling, they feel it detached.
translation_text.mn140:24.4: Feeling the end of the body draw close, they understand: ‘I feel the end of the body draw close.’ Feeling the end of life draw close, they understand: ‘I feel the end of life draw close.’
translation_text.mn140:24.5: They understand: ‘When my body breaks up and my life has come to an end, everything that’s felt, since I no longer take pleasure in it, will become cool right here.’
translation_text.mn140:24.6: Suppose an oil lamp depended on oil and a wick to burn.
translation_text.mn140:24.7: As the oil and the wick are used up, it would be extinguished due to not being fed.
translation_text.mn140:24.8: In the same way, feeling the end of the body draw close, they understand: ‘I feel the end of the body draw close.’ Feeling the end of life draw close, they understand: ‘I feel the end of life draw close.’
translation_text.mn140:24.9: They understand: ‘When my body breaks up and my life has come to an end, everything that’s felt, since I no longer take pleasure in it, will become cool right here.’
translation_text.mn140:25.1: Therefore a mendicant thus endowed is endowed with the ultimate foundation of wisdom.
translation_text.mn140:25.2: For this is the ultimate noble wisdom, namely,
translation_text.mn140:25.3: the knowledge of the ending of all suffering.
translation_text.mn140:26.1: Their freedom, being founded on truth, is unshakable.
translation_text.mn140:26.2: For that which is false has a deceptive nature, while that which is true has an undeceptive nature—extinguishment.
translation_text.mn140:26.3: Therefore a mendicant thus endowed is endowed with the ultimate foundation of truth.
translation_text.mn140:26.4: For this is the ultimate noble truth, namely,
translation_text.mn140:26.5: that which has an undeceptive nature—extinguishment.
translation_text.mn140:27.1: In their ignorance, they used to acquire attachments.
translation_text.mn140:27.2: Those have been cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated so they are unable to arise in the future.
translation_text.mn140:27.3: Therefore a mendicant thus endowed is endowed with the ultimate foundation of generosity.
translation_text.mn140:27.4: For this is the ultimate noble generosity, namely,
translation_text.mn140:28.1: In their ignorance, they used to be covetous, full of desire and lust.
translation_text.mn140:28.2: That has been cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated so it’s unable to arise in the future.
translation_text.mn140:28.3: In their ignorance, they used to be contemptuous, full of ill will and malevolence.
translation_text.mn140:28.4: That has been cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated so it’s unable to arise in the future.
translation_text.mn140:28.5: In their ignorance, they used to be ignorant, full of delusion.
translation_text.mn140:28.6: That has been cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated so it’s unable to arise in the future.
translation_text.mn140:28.7: Therefore a mendicant thus endowed is endowed with the ultimate foundation of peace.
translation_text.mn140:28.8: For this is the ultimate noble peace, namely,
translation_text.mn140:28.9: the pacification of greed, hate, and delusion.
translation_text.mn140:29.1: ‘Do not neglect wisdom; preserve truth; foster generosity; and train only for peace.’
translation_text.mn140:29.2: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.
translation_text.mn140:30.1: ‘Where they stand, the streams of conceiving do not flow. And where the streams of conceiving do not flow, they are called a sage at peace.’
translation_text.mn140:30.2: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?
translation_text.mn140:31.1: These are all forms of conceiving: ‘I am’, ‘I am this’, ‘I will be’, ‘I will not be’, ‘I will have form’, ‘I will be formless’, ‘I will be percipient’, ‘I will be non-percipient’, ‘I will be neither percipient nor non-percipient.’
translation_text.mn140:31.2: Conceiving is a disease, a boil, a dart.
translation_text.mn140:31.3: Having gone beyond all conceiving, one is called a sage at peace.
translation_text.mn140:31.4: The sage at peace is not reborn, does not grow old, and does not die. They are not shaken, and do not yearn.
translation_text.mn140:31.5: For they have nothing which would cause them to be reborn. Not being reborn, how could they grow old? Not growing old, how could they die? Not dying, how could they be shaken? Not shaking, for what could they yearn?
translation_text.mn140:32.1: ‘Where they stand, the streams of conceiving do not flow. And where the streams of conceiving do not flow, they are called a sage at peace.’
translation_text.mn140:32.2: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.
translation_text.mn140:32.3: Mendicant, you should remember this brief analysis of the six elements.”
translation_text.mn140:33.2: “It seems the Teacher has come to me! The Holy One has come to me! The fully awakened Buddha has come to me!” He got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, bowed with his head at the Buddha’s feet, and said,
translation_text.mn140:33.3: “I made a mistake, sir. It was foolish, stupid, and unskillful of me to presume to address the Buddha as ‘reverend’.
translation_text.mn140:33.4: Please, sir, accept my mistake for what it is, so I will restrain myself in future.”
translation_text.mn140:33.5: “Indeed, mendicant, you made a mistake. It was foolish, stupid, and unskillful of you to act in that way.
translation_text.mn140:33.6: But since you have recognized your mistake for what it is, and have dealt with it properly, I accept it.
translation_text.mn140:33.7: For it is growth in the training of the Noble One to recognize a mistake for what it is, deal with it properly, and commit to restraint in the future.”
translation_text.mn140:34.1: “Sir, may I receive the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence?”
translation_text.mn140:34.2: “But mendicant, do you have a full set of bowl and robes?”
translation_text.mn140:34.4: “The Realized Ones do not ordain those without a full set of bowl and robes.”
translation_text.mn140:35.1: And then Venerable Pukkusāti approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.
translation_text.mn140:35.2: But while he was wandering in search of a bowl and robes, a stray cow took his life.
translation_text.mn140:36.1: Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
translation_text.mn140:36.2: “Sir, the gentleman named Pukkusāti, who was advised in brief by the Buddha, has passed away.
translation_text.mn140:36.3: Where has he been reborn in his next life?”
translation_text.mn140:36.4: “Mendicants, Pukkusāti was astute. He practiced in line with the teaching, and did not trouble me about the teachings.
translation_text.mn140:36.5: With the ending of the five lower fetters, he’s been reborn spontaneously and will become extinguished there, not liable to return from that world.”
translation_text.mn140:36.6: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn140:36.7: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
